1.1: Welcome to the Touch Typing Course!
Touch typing is a technique for typing quicker and more accurately by using all ten fingers without looking at the keys.
The core idea is to learn the location of keys by muscle memory. This means your fingers will know where to go without your eyes guiding them.
To begin, place your fingers on the 'Home Row' (A S D F and J K L ;). Your index fingers should rest on F and J.
1.1.2:
Place your fingers on the HOME ROW.

LEFT HAND:
Little finger on A
Ring finger on S
Middle finger on D
Index finger on F

RIGHT HAND:
Index finger on J
Middle finger on K
Ring finger on L
Little finger on ;

2.2.1:
Reach for the top row.

Key E: Use your LEFT MIDDLE finger. Reach up from D.
Key I: Use your RIGHT MIDDLE finger. Reach up from K.

Keep your other fingers on the home row while reaching.
2.2: For best results, practice in short bursts of 15-30 minutes daily. Consistency is more important than duration.
Your brain needs sleep to consolidate muscle memory. So, daily practice with good rest is the secret formula for speed.

3.3: Ergonomics is key to preventing injury.
1. Sit straight with your back supported. 2. Keep your feet flat on the floor.
3. Your screen should be at eye level so you don't bend your neck. 4. Your elbows should be at a 90-degree angle.
Most importantly: float your wrists above the keyboard. Do not rest them on the desk while typing, as this compresses the nerves.

5.5.1:
Use the Shift key to type capital letters.

Use the PINKY finger on the OPPOSITE hand of the letter you are typing.
Example: To type 'A', hold RIGHT SHIFT with right pinky, strike 'A' with left pinky.

5.5: Rhythm is the secret to speed.
Try to type with an even rhythm, like a steady drumbeat or a metronome.
It is better to slow down and type steadily than to sprint through easy words and get stuck on hard ones. A steady pace reduces errors, and fewer errors ultimately means faster typing.
Don't worry about speed for now. Focus on the rhythm.

6.5: It makes a big difference. As you get tired, it's easy to slouch. 1. Keep back straight. 2. Relax shoulders. 3. Elbows at 90 degrees.
If you feel tension in your shoulders, take a deep breath and let them drop. Relaxed muscles move faster.

7.5: Typing for long periods can cause Repetitive Strain Injury (RSI). We recommend the 20-20-20 rule: Every 20 minutes, look at something 20 feet away for 20 seconds.
Also, stand up and stretch every hour to keep good blood flow.

12.5: Regular typing tests help measure your progress. However, don't just focus on speed.
Accuracy is the foundation of speed. If you type fast but make many errors, you will spend more time correcting them than typing.
Aim for 98% accuracy or higher. Speed will naturally follow.

12.7: Congratulations! You have completed the basic course.
You have learned all the alphabet keys and basic punctuation.
So, what is next? 1. Continue practicing to build speed. 2. Learn the number row. 3. Master the special symbols. 4. Try the advanced speed building courses.
